content:
ry 25, 2016
Witches Don't Wear Bras - An Official Waffle King Review~Find more here.[lordwaffleking.com]Swords and junk are pretty cool. When I was little I liked to pretend that sticks were swords and swing them at the kids on the bus stop that I didn't like. They always said to watch out or I'd poke their eyes out. But I showed them. Oh, I showed them. Little did I know, that was little baby Waffle King's first little foray into the world of roleplaying games. I could be whatever I wanted, and I could wield powerful weapons beyond your imagination. Like those perfect sticks that make whistling noises when you swing them.As I grew older, of course RPG games would be a genre I got pulled back to time and time again. But in this day and age, true roleplaying games have become harder to come by. The big guys upstairs, the game publishers that control what we play, they don't want those. Because you know what, those games are hard. They're really hard. Making choices is hard. Consequences are hard. It's so much easier if you can just mash buttons and make things happen. And if you want to learn every skill? You can do that. It's okay.Hardcore RPG's aren't a genre that's explored often by big publishers. They're a niche type of game. One of the biggest developers of RPG's of that nature, Bioware, is still around. But sadly, there's a lot of corporate fingers in their ♥♥♥.They've made some of the greatest RPG classics. And some other games. Those were alright. Even after being acquired by EA, they still put out a number of quality games. Before, you know. It happened. RIP.Dragon Tales Origins was one of the first games to come out under the new EA and Bioware partnership, launching on Xbox 360, Playstation 3, and PC; it's a spiritual successor to Neverwinter Nights and the acclaimed Baldur's Gate games.Ever watch that one movie Lord of the Rings? Kinda like that, only you get to bang a witch.She doesn't really wear clothes or anything. She has some shower curtains or something over her shoulder.Dragon Tales is a pretty good game. A hardcore tactical strategy RPG, with an emphasis on the roleplaying aspect. You become the guy with the sword that does the things. You are him or her. You get to bang that witch and save the world. It's all you, buddy.A grand tale of zombies and witch ♥♥♥♥♥♥s, Dragon Tales Origins is extremely heavy with lore. They really went all out trying to build this fantasy world. They got the elves, the dwarves, and all that good stuff. Completely original lore, totally not just Lord of the Rings with some things switched around. In fact, they were so proud of their work they even went and named it Origins. They were planning ahead. They already knew it was gonna be big. They were gonna make a series out of it from the very beginning. And ♥♥♥♥, they really wrote a ♥♥♥♥ing book. It's a book, a book with some RPG elements mixed in. I didn't pay attention in History class, the ♥♥♥♥ you think I'm gonna memorize the lore of Dragon Tales for?It's written well at least, and the characters are a joy to be around. They're colorful and multi-dimensional, and you can sex them all up. Not all at once, they get mad at you for trying to do that. Which is definitely holding me back from giving the game a perfect score. You can even do gay things in Origins, one of the defining features that made it so popular with the Tumblr crowd. You can gay things up, and that is clearly what gay people look for most in their games. They're mostly awkward teenage girls actually, they love gay sex more than actual gay people. But you know, this is exactly what they look for in a game and they're free to like what they like.Writing would be what I'd say is Dragon Tales' best trait. It's visually a little dated, with a pretty good soundtrack. But the writing, ooh wee, that's some good swords and magic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. An RPG like Origins thrives on writing, though. It's all about pulling you in, letting you live the role of a dude with a sword in a medieval setting.The only problem with this setup is that the game mechanics aren't quite welcoming to the whole swords thing. In fact, I really wouldn't recommend using swords at all. Just don't, for your own good.You get to build your own character and assign them one of several backstories, races, and classes. It encourages you to make many different characters, to see the story from different angles and to make different choices to see the outcome should you have made one choice instead of the other. But what the game fails to encourage is using any class other than mage. Really, the mage is the best thing to play and is the only thing I'd recommend.A knight or warrior's job is to walk into monsters and take up space while mages attack and heal. Rogues are fun also, allowing you free rein over the battlefield to just kinda walk around, stab guys in the back, and all that good stuff. But mages get the most cool things to use. Exploding lightning, blizzards, and summoning giant spiders and ♥♥♥♥. It's the definitive way to play this game by a long shot. Not to mention how poorly balanced they are. If you're fighting enemies and there's an enemy mage, you gun for that guy first because he can crush your entire party in no time. And it's the exact same vice versa. So you're gonna want to take good care of your mage.You get to order your party members around as well, so if you do choose to make your main character something other than the best class in the game you can always just play as ♥♥♥♥♥ witch. Who is the best character in the game.Ordering around your allies isn't exactly optional however. They don't really have much in terms of AI. Their default tactics are to headbutt monsters while singing the U.S. National Anthem, The Star-Spangled Banner. Classic song, great song. But it helps out much more if you can command them to fight strategically. You have to pretty much program them through a bunch of clunky menus, which is my favorite thing in a game. You know me, I like my menus how I like that ♥♥♥. Hard to handle and all over the place. If it takes me less than ten minutes to get from Point A to Point B, it just isn't clunky enough. I want to spend hours trying to work that ♥♥♥. Menus and asses like that are a true work of perfection and are the clear indicator of brilliant game design. Swapping between characters on the fly works well if you're gonna fight that way also, but also can be very intensive during major fights.I'd still consider it one of my favorite RPG's, even if it has numerous little flaws and hasn't aged well in some regards. I've enjoyed multiple playthroughs, and it is still fun the second and third time. There's definitely a clear right way to play it, which is as a mage and on PC. Keyboard shortcuts, hotkeys, and the superior camera controls and options really make it the definitive way to play. But it's still decently enjoyable however you should tackle it. PC users have mods though also, so you can see uncensored ♥♥♥♥♥♥s and stuff. That's why people mod stuff in the first place.It's a wordy game, full of reading and numbers and nerd things. But it's immersive and fun, and a testament to Bioware's secret formula to making some of the best RPG's. Well it's not exactly a secret, you just need to be able to sex people, commit genocide, and unite the many tribes to vanquish a great evil that you told everyone was coming and no one listened.Dragon Tales always reminds me of raisins though. When I first played it, I was just kind of marathon-playing it and needed a snack. But there was nothing at all to eat in my house. Nothing but raisins. And it was a giant industrial-size can of raisins too. It had like 100 servings or something. So I just ate raisins while I played. That's all I had. I've learned from my mistakes, and I keep other things stocked up now. You just gotta live and learn, man. Just live and learn.

												This is easily one of my favorite games of all time. The plot is completely fascinating, the characters feel like real people, and your choices will have far-reaching consequences. 												Dragon Age: Origins was the game that set the bar for me when it comes to fantasty RPGs. It is, without a doubt, one of my favorite games ever. The story is compelling, extremely dark and well-thought through. There wasn't a moment when I felt the game was bad, even if it has a few frustrating parts. content:
y 26, 2014
												I overall enjoyed this game and consider it Bioware's swan song. The origin story chosen by the player impacts not only your dialogue options, but also the level of classism and fantastical racism encountered. The female Dalish elf has few rights, lives in poverty(walled off segregated part of the city), and gets taken to be a mistress for the local noble. She has little social mobility and only gets out of her scenario from being enlisted by the Gray Wardens. There is no social justice, only results matter from her actions afterward. This provided for me a sense of agency in my actions versus being dropped into say roleplaying as Geralt of Rivia in the Witcher series. The Noble female noble’s story is also one of revenge. Yet she can still do more. She can by my count simultaneously be: Queen consort of Fereldan, Teyrna of Gwaren, the second in line heir to Highever, Commander of the Grey in Fereldan, and Arlessa of Amaranthine. That is like... Michelle Obama if she was also Governor of Florida, heir of California, and Mayor of New York City and Marshal General of all the armed forces. There are many origins but only one Duncan to help that origin character. The others origin characters are dead if they do not get enlisted. The player can encounter the Dwarf commoner’s corpse in a part of the plot. With no Duncan to enlist him, he refuses to eat and thus dies in prison. The format of the vanilla campaign follows the usual Bioware formula. The main character must travel to four locations, solve the local issues and convince that faction to help in the final battle. You are hunted by the darkspawn and will encounter a vision/dream sequence with the big bad. As you travel you will encounter the ruins of an ancient civilization (lost dwarven thaigs/Prothiens/Underdark) lost over time yet full of artifact tier items and lore. The gameplay is similar to Baldur’s gate but does not rely on the daily spell count limit of D&D gameplay. Mages are far stronger than many other classes for regular enemies. With some exceptions such as the Gaxkang lich battle. This game reminded me of Baldur’s Gate a lot. If the Warden badly handles decisions, party members will leave the party and even challenge you for leadership. The backgrounds of the characters should be considered in your political dealings. During the Landsmeet, if you arranged for Anora and Alistair to marry it can backfire if you let Loghain live and join the order to redeem himself. To conscript Loghain into the Wardens will make Alistair furious. To Alistair, joining the Grey Wardens is a sacred duty and honor, it is not a death sentence. By contrast, if you let Alistair execute Logain, Anora will break down the political alliance as she cannot marry the killer of her father. What I found charming in this game was the fact that character interactions and growth seems to happen naturally. Alistair’s reception to mages was something I felt was handled very well. His early training was that of a Templar, a role sworn to strike down mages if they are taken over by demons of the Fade. Yet Alistair is scared of Morrigan and neutral to Wynne. At first glance you may think he hates all mages. But the reason he distrusts Morrigan so much is not just because she is a mage. Rather the issue is that Morrigan is a maleficar, someone outside of the rules of the Chantry. She practices unknown magic (shapeshifting, is neutral to blood magic rituals, etc) that he has been taught all of his life is evil and wrong. He is actually terrified of her.

content:
0, 2014
												This is one of the last BIoWare games that *felt* like a BioWare game after their acquisition by Electronic Arts. It is a RTwP RPG with a pretty average main plot, but what makes it shine is the excellent writing and personalities of the companions you pick up on your adventure to stop the big-bad. If you play this game the right way, you will grow attached to the characters after spending 20-40 hours killing monsters with them, learning about their past, goals and desires along the way. Each character is distinct from one another, and fleshed out to make you really care about their ultimate fate. That doesn't stop you from being a complete scum bag to them, which yeilds its own rewards in the form of comedy (At least for me)The combat system is accessible, but not simplistic enough that you can go into each battle and not use tactics, (Not on higher difficulty settings at least).  Some battles require a great deal of thinking in order to devise the perfect strategy to take down a large group of enemies, or a tough boss. There are a large number of skills and talents to learn as you level up, as well as 3 different classes to choose from (Rogue, Mage, Warrior) which each have a few of their own sub-classes called specializations which also hold different abilities to learn, which makes the game extremely replayable right off the bat, even if there weren't multiple ending (Which there are). But there are also different Origin stories, as the title suggests. Dwarven Noble, Dwarven Commoner, Dalish Elf, City Elf, Human Noble and Circle Mage, which adds even more replayability since each origin story and race choice changes certain dialogues, the opening act and even certain missions down the road.Those who can't get enough swag will be delighted to know that there are plenty of epic armor, weapons and other loots to be found here to slaughter things with, which makes it a pleasure to play if you can't get enough of the cosmetic side of RPGs. The only thing I have a problem with is that the mage class has a very limited selection of rather boring robes to sport, and that is disappointing. There are also plenty of sidequests to complete over the course of your adventure, which range from dull fetch quests to epic dragon slaying.So in conclusion, the game is quite good. The characters are memorable, the combat is fun and challenging, plenty of armor and weapons to choose from, multiple endings and hours of content to play. It is well worth the money, in my opinion.That is all.

												Brilliant game. Excellent choice&consequence, extensive lore, solid RPG mechanics and combat, though held back a lot by over-reliance on the MMO healer-tank-DPS archetype, instead of sticking with the D&D mechanics that made Baldur's Gate great. But still, the combat is engaging and never too easy. A lot of content also - 54 hours in and I have only completed the main game; I still have to do all the DLCs as well as the expansion pack Awakening. Dragon Age: Origins was probably one of the best RPGs in the few years before and after its release. It's a shame about the sequels because Bioware could have turned this franchise into something truly great. Origins looks, feels, and plays like a cRPG, and was developed primarily for PC, but its sequels had a console audience in mind and it shows. The squandered potential of Dragon Age is just one more thing EA has run into the ground.

content:
6, 2015
												Graphically this game is starting to show it's age (this can be somewhat compensated for however with mods), but despite some awkward animation here and there it still looks beautiful and is a joy to play. Of all the Dragon Age games I'd say that Dragon Age: Origins and Awakening are still the best. DA:O offers the most diversity in character creation, roll playing, and character building than in any other Dragon Age game.Dragon Age: Origins - Ultimate Edition comes with the main game which will take approximately 60hours to complete if you do everything. It also comes with every piece of purchaseable DLC.-Warden's Keep; travel to Soldiers Peak to discover what happened to cause the Grey Warden's to be exiled from Fereldan 200 years prior to the events of the game (also adds 2 new abilites per class and a storage chest for items)-Stone Prisoner; aquire a Golem companion character named Shale-Lelianna's Song; you play the events that lead to one of your companion character's ending up in the Lothering Chantry (completion unlocks items for Origins/Awakening)-Darkspawn Chronicles; this DLC is a "what if" scenario for Fereldan if your character had died just after the prologue (completion unlocks items for Origins/Awakening)-Dragon Age: Awakening; this expansion sees you, or a new character, rebuild the Grey Warden order in Fereldan after the events of Dragon Age: Origins. This expansion alone adds an aditional 30hours playtime at least.-Witch Hunt; find out what happened to Morrigan, one of your key companion characters, after the events of DA:O (completion unlocks items for Origins/Awakening)You can also go to the Bioware website using your EA account to unlock all the promotional items (preorder bonuses and sh*t like that) for free.This game boasts an epic story, memorable characters, and creates the foundation that the other games have used to stand on. The other games have their own epic tales, but they all lack the same kind of urgency you get from playing DA:O and trying to thwart the 5th blight. This game is great value at it's RRP, but if you see it on sale I'd say it's a must buy.

content:
6, 2015
												Graphically this game is starting to show it's age (this can be somewhat compensated for however with mods), but despite some awkward animation here and there it still looks beautiful and is a joy to play. Of all the Dragon Age games I'd say that Dragon Age: Origins and Awakening are still the best. DA:O offers the most diversity in character creation, roll playing, and character building than in any other Dragon Age game.Dragon Age: Origins - Ultimate Edition comes with the main game which will take approximately 60hours to complete if you do everything. It also comes with every piece of purchaseable DLC.-Warden's Keep; travel to Soldiers Peak to discover what happened to cause the Grey Warden's to be exiled from Fereldan 200 years prior to the events of the game (also adds 2 new abilites per class and a storage chest for items)-Stone Prisoner; aquire a Golem companion character named Shale-Lelianna's Song; you play the events that lead to one of your companion character's ending up in the Lothering Chantry (completion unlocks items for Origins/Awakening)-Darkspawn Chronicles; this DLC is a "what if" scenario for Fereldan if your character had died just after the prologue (completion unlocks items for Origins/Awakening)-Dragon Age: Awakening; this expansion sees you, or a new character, rebuild the Grey Warden order in Fereldan after the events of Dragon Age: Origins. This expansion alone adds an aditional 30hours playtime at least.-Witch Hunt; find out what happened to Morrigan, one of your key companion characters, after the events of DA:O (completion unlocks items for Origins/Awakening)You can also go to the Bioware website using your EA account to unlock all the promotional items (preorder bonuses and sh*t like that) for free.This game boasts an epic story, memorable characters, and creates the foundation that the other games have used to stand on. The other games have their own epic tales, but they all lack the same kind of urgency you get from playing DA:O and trying to thwart the 5th blight. This game is great value at it's RRP, but if you see it on sale I'd say it's a must buy.

content:

												I LOVE BioWare RPGs, and I ♥♥♥♥ing -LOVE- Dragon Age: Origins!I first played it on Xbox 360, and then replayed it, and replayed it, seriously about fifteen times (plus every 'origin' story), not to mention all the time spent to unlock certain achievements.The game has a myriad of complex, flawed and ultimately loveable (or loathable) characters, with a consequence (or reward) for your every action. content:
er 19, 2013
												Dragon Age: Origins offers one of the best single-player rpg experiences on th PC. It has a rich and detailed lore surrounding the game world that sets up the stage for your adventures in the game. The main story is also very intriguing and is full of twists and turns that will keep you entertained for the whole ride. It also offers many side-quests that flesh out the world with many unique stories, and every conversation you have reveals more information about the world of Dragon Age. If you love a good fantasy world, than Dragon Age doesn’t fail to disappoint.The story is the traditional Bioware set-up, with a bit of a twist. When you create your character, you get to pick a race, an origin and a gender. Depending on your choices, the characters in the world will treat you differently. More importantly, you play a short 30-60 minute intro story that is unique to your origin. Then there is a 30-60 minute general intro sequence that you play, before the world opens up. You have to travel to multiple different locations, in any order you choose, in order to get different factions to pledge their loyalty to you for a battle against the game’s main enemy, the Darkspawn. Each area you go to have its own problems that you must sort out before they will pledge allegiance to you. Like everything you do in Dragon Age, solving these problems tells you more about the society and world of Dragon Age. The story continues on and ends in a grand finale. The main is very interesting.

content:
r 22, 2016
PROS:+ 6 different origin stories (tied to 3 races & 3 classes)+ epic main campaign+ party banter+ companions & their stories+ TONS of decisions that affect the story+ complex skill tree+ fantastic mod support+ special finishing moves+ superior combat tactics to other DA games+ UE has additional missions inside the main campaign - Warden's Keep, Stone Prisoner, Return to Ostagar+ UE has additional DLC campaigns to main story - Awakening, Golems of Amgarrak, Witch Hunt+ UE has alternate DLC campaigns - Leliana's Song, A Tale of Orzammar, Darkspawn ChroniclesCONS:- some skills can be buggy under certain circumstances- decisions can glitch out when exporting between main campaign and the additional DLC campaigns- couple of promotional DLC items are missing in Ultimate Edition on Steam- majority of the DLC items become useless very early in the campaignComment:I bought this game, again, here on Steam because it is such a good game. I would say one of my favourite games ever.  At first you choose between 3 races - humans, elfs, dwarves and then between 3 classes. Afterwards you get to pick an origin. The six various origins make you start the game at various places and this adds to the roleplay element. Eventually all origin stories continue into the main story at Ostagar, but even after that your origin affects how NPCs react to your character. The main campaign has that epic quest feeling to it and I cannot say much without spoiling. The main premise is a darkspawn invasion led by the archdemon and you are the last hope to stop it. On your way you will pick up companions and solve various side quests ... or you won't, it's your choice. Either way there is a huge amount of content here that will get you playing for many many many hours. That is even expanded upon by the expansion Awakening, DLC Golems of Amgarrak and DLC Witch Hunt ... all of these can share 1 character that you import from the main campaign. The mod support is really really good in this game. It is easy to get into and even I made a mod and helped on some others. This support is a bit worse in DA2 and basically non-existant in DA:Inquisition. And that is a shame because mod support is one of the things that keeps games alive very long and bolsters the fandom around the game itself. The graphics are not as pretty as newer DA games but it still has a certain old RPG charm. And mods can fix a lot of the character models in the game or adjust the look to your liking. EA involvement was already visible here with 2 DLC missions and a DLC companion on game release. Despite that, the DLC feel fun for the most part. I could go on about every campaign and mission available here but it is too much and all you REALLY need to know is that the majority of it is fun and worth playing if you are into RPG games. Enjoy!

content:
3, 2014
												If you prefer your RPGs to be story- and character-heavy (at the cost of, say, wide-ranging open-endedness) and party-focused then this is a beautiful game.Some strengths and weaknesses:+ Story.  There's quite a bit of writing in here.  It's mostly serious but there's quite a bit of intentional comedy.  Don't forget the DLCs.   "Golems of Amgarrak" wasn't anything special, but "Leilana's Song" is a nice short prequel.+ Lots of side quests+ Characters; a number have a good bit of story and personality to them.  Voice acting helps a good deal.+ Decent game flow and control; pause+give orders, cooldowns, limited scripting ability+ Modest system requirements compared to today's hardware, but still pretty+ Mostly quite usable UI; plenty of room for skills on the quick-selection bar, for instance+ Old enough that it's a likely on-sale target, and will be an excellent bargain when that happens+ Range in difficulty settings; if you're playing for the story rather than as a hard-core gam3r l33t, set it to the lowest difficulty and you'll be fine, for instance~ Some flexibility; the story arc is mostly set out, but there's still a fair bit heavily influenced by your choices~ No main-mission timer; you can complete many, many side quests if you wish.  This gives flexibility and allows you to experience more, but some may find it bad for immersion when you're undertaking these and seemingly not treating the Big Bad with as much urgency as it might demand.- Instability; crash bugs, at least if making heavy use of magic- Occasional but sometimes very nasty scripting bugs- Sometimes awkward camera positioning.  There were definitely times I'd wished for having either a true first-person view (rather than over-the-shoulder third), a true straight-down view, and/or transparency controls for walls, arches, etc.- A few notable UI omissions like no estimates of value unless you're at a merchant- Yet another RPG where you can't scribble notes on the map, *sigh*

content:
er 12, 2013
												Dragon Age is a fantastic RPG that lasted longer than I thought it would. I finished it in 40 hours, but it could easily take you 20 hours longer to complete everything.The characters have depth, the story is pretty good, the graphics also still look very good and the gameplay is tight for a 3D RPG. It can be a bit unbalanced at times though, so I had to change the difficulty from time to time in order to advance. It's disappointing but, it never really frustrates. The isometric view is actually very helpful and, in my opinion, works better than the default camera view. I do admit that the default view is the more cinematic one, but for the later battles isometric view is recommended, required even.Dragon Age is a title that I immensely enjoyed. It's one of the better RPGs of the last decade so if RPG is your thing you should definitely play this.(Play the second one as well. Despite the repetitiveness of the environments it's also well worth a playthrough and it's not as bad as people say it is).[Rating: 92/100]

number of helpful: 17 of 31 people (55%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
y 19
												Recommended, but only with reservations.It doesn't run completely stable. I've had it crash several times when opening the party's inventory screen directly after a larger fight in the city of Denerim. Other players have had similar crashes years ago already. The Wiki mentions various bugs in quests and other parts of the game.The game's playtime is long enough, if it's your first playthrough without following any guides/walkthroughs. If you want to rush through the game a single time, note that some guides are controversial.The game's is easy enough at "Normal" difficulty, and even more so, if you don't mind reloading an older save from time to time. Such as when you've found out something that's not explained in the manual.The included manual only gives a very sketchy picture of how everything works. Don't expect to find any maths in there. Searching the Wiki and discussion forums will be needed, if you're interested in details, such as how exactly an attribute influences a skill's efficiency.Combat is very repetitive, especially since the party's size is limited to your player character and only three NPC companions, which you control. Companions, which you remove from the party, remain available at the party's camp site till the end of the game. I think the skill/talent tree has been dumbed down pretty much. The variety of enemies could be much greater.It is not an open world. Quest locations on the overview map get added/removed as you progress through the game. The quest areas themselves often are very restricted, and even in the wilderness you can only move through an area on predefined paths and not move freely.In some parts of the game you enter meta-gaming hell. Such as an ambiguous answer during conversation leading to an immediate and unexpected ambush of a potential companion, because that's how some of the conversation trees have been designed. Reload and avoid the WTF-moment. Or one of your long-time companions, who has been with you almost since the beginning and  calls you a friend, leaves permanently before the last few endgame fights just because the game only offers two story-driven choices for taking either the evil or good path. Or merchants at various stages of the game, who offer unlimited supplies of some very important crafting materials or a recipe you need. Once you've gained such meta-gaming knowledge, the real planning can start. Or else the potential for multiple playthroughs would be low.If you only want to do a single playthrough, the game is entertaining enough for sure. Its beginning varies in quality. Don't quit in rage early. The middle and end are better. The voice acting is fine, but sometimes a bit silly (they couldn't resist adding crap when you select a companion). And there are lots of cutscenes that add to the atmosphere.

y 18, 2016
												This game. Is. Amazing. There's nothing more to be said about it. There's 0 reason to not own this game if you like RPGs of any kind. Especially since it's $7 right now for the main game and ALL of the DLC? GET IT! I still have this game on ps3. I bought it back in the day when it came out. I re bought it for DLC. I wont talk about or ruin the story for anyone, but it is by far one of the best stories in gaming. The fight at the end made me cry. I cant recall a single other game that was powerfull enough to bring a tear to my eyes. The bonds you make with the members of your party is absolutely amazing. They feel like genuine real life flesh and blood people as you listen to their stories about their life. There's no other word for it. "Amazing ". On top of all that, there's remarkable replayability as you can choose several different origins that change the story up immensely. And each of the story lines has one of two factons you can side with, which will immediately make you want to replay through it and see what happens on the other side. As soon as you finish this game if you agreed to morigans deal ( which I wont spoil ) you will IMMEDIATELY want to play the witch hunt dlc. And all of this, this is just the MAIN game. Theres so much content here it almost makes up a second whole new game. I can not praise this game high enough, it's in my top 5 games of all time, i've clocked countless hours on this on PS3, pick this up. 10/10.

content:
, 2014
												One of the best RPG out there, with hours upon hours of content, especially if you get the Ultimate Edition which brings all the game's DLC in the bundle, adding even more hours of gameplay and some interesting campaigns that differ from the main one, showing us more about certain characters, even allowing us to taste being part of the evil faction.I will add here some points that go for the game and some that go against it.Pros:+It is a long game with a lot of content, a rare thing to find these days.+It's side quests are where the game really shines, with a lot of ways to entertain the player in many different ways.+Your choices change things in the world around you.+It's background story is astoundingly well developed (As we have come to expect from bioware since games like KOTOR)+The PC version has a more in depth tactical mechanic than its console counterpart, you can pause the game at any time to    give orders to your followers or to plan how to tackle certain enemies.+Various origins to choose from that affect dialogues troughout the game. (Hence the game's title)+Many build options and various specs branching from three base classes: Warrior, Mage and Rogue.Cons:-If you are someone that values graphics over other things keep in mind that this game came out in 2009, so it is bound to be graphicaly outdated (The graphics aren't bad tough).-The main storyline is kind of typical and straightforward, and depending on your choices it might end in a way that leaves you with a bitter taste.-The relationship system with your followers is not that well done, you might find that the character you are trying to romance in their highes approval level and still don't show any interest in taking your friendship further.-It has mods, but the game's modding mechanics are kind of tough to get acustomed with, especially if you are new to modding games.All in all it is a very good game and while it isn't perfect, since it is a mess to activate the dlc for some people, for example, it is a game that I do sincerely recommend.10/10 -would play again-

content:
ry 9, 2014
												In the veins of Baldur's Gate, with relatively modern yet deep control scheme - the game that can be played in many different ways.A big plus is the option to choose a difficulty setting (and change it during the game as you wish), and the game's ability to tune the monsters to your own level, thus always providing a reasonable challenge.The story of DAO is captivating and very well thought-through, there are no big head-scratchers or points where the game would take your freedom of choice away. Each major plotline has at least 2 very different ways to resolve it, and you can on several occasions try to "play it for both sides", which results in some cool plot twists.I'd also like to highlight the fantastic Fade - this game's "Mental world", which you will visit on several occasions and where you face demons and emotions in place of ordinary monsters. This is one of the best portrayals of spiritual world I have seen.It is easy to forgive this game the few issues it has (such as the inability to plan ambushes for those enemies who have a conversation prior to the fight), because the game, as a whole, is a masterpiece.

content:
y 7, 2014
SummaryA captivating RPG experience that easily stands shoulder to shoulder with classics like Fallout and Planescape: Torment.ReviewDragon Age: Origins is, in a word, awesome. Think of everything you love (and some things you might hate) about role-playing games, and that's DA:O.I'll get the bad things out of the way first simply because there are so few of them. First of all, there is tons of combat in this game. That's both a good and a bad thing, though. The combat system is, in fact, extremely well designed, interesting, and most importantly loads of fun. The problem is that there's sometimes too much of it which can feel like a bit of a meaningless slog on occasion, especially during some of the lengthier travel segments. My second criticism is that sometimes dialog choices don't actually make any difference during conversations and lead to the same generic response from an NPC. Thankfully, this is largely the exception.And that's it, really. Everything else about the game is absolutely stellar. The hallmark of the RPG genre is meaningful choices and consequences, and DA:O excels in this area. Quests have multiple solutions, conversations often play out radically differently depending on player choice, and your decisions during quests and conversations have an impact on your companions' relationships with your character. Consequences can be minor, such as lowering a companion's disposition towards you, while others are more substantial, affecting and sometimes limiting your available options later in the game. It all feels very natural and dynamic, and you'll often find yourself wondering what would happen if you had made different choices which contributes to DA:O's excellent replay value. Quite often these choices are not black and white with obvious "right" and "wrong" paths laid out before you, and you'll often find yourself trying to untangle a moral quandary. For instance, when a young boy is possessed by a demon, do you defeat the demon by killing the boy, or by allowing his mother to sacrifice herself in a blood magic ritual? There's no easy answer to that sort of dilemma, and many of DA:O's quests hinge on such decisions.The lack of moral certainty is refreshing for this genre, because it allows you to play a nuanced evil character, offering role playing choices that are deeper and more interesting than the usual "evil guy = jerk" one-dimensional characterization that many RPG's tend towards. It also happens that the morally good choices do not always bring the best rewards, so the player isn't at an automatic disadvantage for not walking the straight and narrow.DA:O features an epic story that could possibly be criticized for riffing on Tolkien, but then, what fantasy story doesn't? However, BioWare added enough of their own unique twists to the setting and narrative that they can legitimately call it their own. One area where DA:O shines in particular is how well realized the game world is. It's clear that BioWare put a lot of time and thought into this aspect of the game and developed a detailed and plausible society. Everything from history, local politics, national politics, religion, cultural divisions, and the plight of the common man is fleshed out in considerable detail making Ferelden feel more like a real place than a fictional world. I personally found the dwarven culture with its rigid caste system to be particularly fascinating. To give you an idea of the kind of attention to detail we're talking about, BioWare doesn't just declare that it's based on a caste system and that's it but actually delves into ancient dwarven history to explain exactly how the system developed in the first place. Much of this information is conveyed through codex entries which unlock as you progress through the game, and there is, in fact, quite a lot of reading to be done in DA:O, but it's well worth your time and perhaps even necessary to get the most out of your experience.And what an experience it is. The main game will take you around 60-hours to complete, and if you get the Ultimate Edition (and you should) you can add another 20-hours for the Awakening expansion plus several more besides for some of the smaller campaigns like Witch Hunt and The Dark Spawn Chronicles, so there's around a hundred hours of gameplay for your first play-through, and with its branching storyline, interesting moral choices, and 6 unique origins stories based on your choice of character, there's plenty of incentive to play again and again.Trust me, this is one you do not want to miss.

content:
er 28, 2013
												DA:O has got to be one of the best RPG's I've played to date. It has an engrossing story, a fleshed out world with interesting and likeable characters. In terms of gameplay it relies on strategic thinking. You can pause in the middle of battle and zoom out into an almost isometric view to get a better look at the battlefield. This allows you to think of where to place your party members and what abilities will work best against a certain enemy. You can even do a cross-class combo, such as having a mage freeze an enemy and then have a warrior bash them with their shield, shattering them thus killing them instantly. But because of this style of play it may not be to everyone's taste. And its does have its fair share of flaws but overall, it is a good game. I really recommand getting it.

content:
y 17, 2015
												This review is for "Dragon Age: Origins - Ultimate Edition", that is, including all DLCs and the Awakening expansionDragon Age Origins, despite its...age (dates back to 2009) is still the best classic RPG and the only true spiritual successor of Baldur's Gate.PROS+ The game is huge. A completist walkthrough (there are hundreds of missions and side quests and endless dialogues) can easily take 130 hours.+ The tactical combat is very good.+ As of 2014 the best storyline ever.+ Fantastic characterization of companions, allies and foes.+ Truly epic+ Strong replayability (different  routes, different endings)+ Good, detailed graphics + Excellent voice acting+ Easy to use GUICons- While the main story (Origins) is polished, the follow up (Awakening) is still (and will always be, considering it's 5 years old) buggy, with a weaker story line and loses a bit of the high impact involvement with companions.- No voice acting for the main character (for some reason, they did not go the Mass Effect way).The sequel, Dragon Age 2, is a completely different game (more like an action rpg, buggy, with a weak storyline and silly game mechanics)), so don't bother.Overall 9,5/10 Dragon Age: Origins stands as the Golden Standard for all RPGs

content:
er 15, 2014
												If you enjoy rpgs driven by story and the choices you make having an impact I recommend  this game for you! This game has a multiple companions that can either love or hate you based on your decisions. Also many of your decisions impact the world in some way or another. The overarching story is seen as generic by some and in someways it is, but it is still a very good story. On the combat side of things this game has party based combat in the style of Baldur's gate where you compose a party consisting of you and 3 companions of your choice.  I would recommend getting the ultimate edition over the regular edition because the awakening expansion is very enjoyable. The other dlcs also add to the game and are fun aswell.  You will get many hours of enjoyment out of this game, not only is one playthrough long but there is a lot of replayability due to how many class combinations and decisions you can make. So overall I think this game is well worth the 30 dollar price tag but it is a good decision to wait for a sale as it usually drops to around 7 dollars which is an amazing price for how great this game is. I would give it a 9/10.

content:
y 25, 2012
												Easily the best RPG I've ever played. In fact, as of the writing of this review, I'd go as far as to call this the single greatest game I've played on any platform - and that's coming from someone who's been gaming since Atari.Dragon age is a powerful, engrossing experience. The world is massive, the back-story immense. If lore is your thing, you'll find scattered throughout Ferelden enough lore to fill 9 novels. The characters are EASILY the best developed I've ever encountered. Spend enough time playing and you really feel like you connect with them. They have so much personality; and their voice acting is flawless. It really makes you care about them. The combat is polished and perfect for PC (if you played on console and were frustrated, it's not even REMOTELY equivalent. Being able to lay out all your attacks and click the ones you want is much more natural) - lots of strategy and customization options. Perhaps best of all is the story. I've never played a game that's done a better job of presenting the player with choices that will truly alter the story on the fly. This gives it IMMENSE replay value. I've played through this game a dozen times, and it was wildly different every time.If you've grown disenchanted with the increasingly j-pop influenced Final Fantasy series, try Dragon Age

content:
ry 16, 2015
												As in most of the games I play I am very LTTP, but I enjoyed the story lines and world created in this game. While I normally don't play DLC (unless I really enjoyed the main game), I felt like the DLCs in this case built nicely upon what was created in the main game. Dragon Age Awakening was practically a sequel (a short one, but a lot of stand alone games are around the same length).I hate to compare it to Mass Effect, but I am going to anyway. One thing I noticed on my DA play through was I didn't love the characters the same way I loved the ME characters. I didn't make sure I did all the companion quests, etc and didn't even really feel compelled to romance any of the companions. So in a way for me, the story wasn't as character driven as Mass Effect, if that makes sense, but I still found myself enjoying the overall story arc, combat and world.The combat took some getting used to. At first I didn't like the pausing mechanic, but I found later as some of the fights got more complicated in terms of positioning ranged players or having a companion change tactics it made it way more fun. The tactics menu was also an awesome idea. Most of the time I went with the default tactics, but found myself slightly modifying them as I went further into the game. Basically the pausing mechanic and being able to change tactics really added to the game in a big way, setting it apart from other action RPGs.I plan on playing DA2 soon, but I don't own it on Steam unfortunately.

content:
ry 9, 2014
												In the veins of Baldur's Gate, with relatively modern yet deep control scheme - the game that can be played in many different ways.A big plus is the option to choose a difficulty setting (and change it during the game as you wish), and the game's ability to tune the monsters to your own level, thus always providing a reasonable challenge.The story of DAO is captivating and very well thought-through, there are no big head-scratchers or points where the game would take your freedom of choice away. Each major plotline has at least 2 very different ways to resolve it, and you can on several occasions try to "play it for both sides", which results in some cool plot twists.I'd also like to highlight the fantastic Fade - this game's "Mental world", which you will visit on several occasions and where you face demons and emotions in place of ordinary monsters. This is one of the best portrayals of spiritual world I have seen.It is easy to forgive this game the few issues it has (such as the inability to plan ambushes for those enemies who have a conversation prior to the fight), because the game, as a whole, is a masterpiece.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												One of the best RPG out there, with hours upon hours of content, especially if you get the Ultimate Edition which brings all the game's DLC in the bundle, adding even more hours of gameplay and some interesting campaigns that differ from the main one, showing us more about certain characters, even allowing us to taste being part of the evil faction.I will add here some points that go for the game and some that go against it.Pros:+It is a long game with a lot of content, a rare thing to find these days.+It's side quests are where the game really shines, with a lot of ways to entertain the player in many different ways.+Your choices change things in the world around you.+It's background story is astoundingly well developed (As we have come to expect from bioware since games like KOTOR)+The PC version has a more in depth tactical mechanic than its console counterpart, you can pause the game at any time to    give orders to your followers or to plan how to tackle certain enemies.+Various origins to choose from that affect dialogues troughout the game. (Hence the game's title)+Many build options and various specs branching from three base classes: Warrior, Mage and Rogue.Cons:-If you are someone that values graphics over other things keep in mind that this game came out in 2009, so it is bound to be graphicaly outdated (The graphics aren't bad tough).-The main storyline is kind of typical and straightforward, and depending on your choices it might end in a way that leaves you with a bitter taste.-The relationship system with your followers is not that well done, you might find that the character you are trying to romance in their highes approval level and still don't show any interest in taking your friendship further.-It has mods, but the game's modding mechanics are kind of tough to get acustomed with, especially if you are new to modding games.All in all it is a very good game and while it isn't perfect, since it is a mess to activate the dlc for some people, for example, it is a game that I do sincerely recommend.10/10 -would play again-

content:
er 15, 2014
												If you enjoy rpgs driven by story and the choices you make having an impact I recommend  this game for you! This game has a multiple companions that can either love or hate you based on your decisions. Also many of your decisions impact the world in some way or another. The overarching story is seen as generic by some and in someways it is, but it is still a very good story. On the combat side of things this game has party based combat in the style of Baldur's gate where you compose a party consisting of you and 3 companions of your choice.  I would recommend getting the ultimate edition over the regular edition because the awakening expansion is very enjoyable. The other dlcs also add to the game and are fun aswell.  You will get many hours of enjoyment out of this game, not only is one playthrough long but there is a lot of replayability due to how many class combinations and decisions you can make. So overall I think this game is well worth the 30 dollar price tag but it is a good decision to wait for a sale as it usually drops to around 7 dollars which is an amazing price for how great this game is. I would give it a 9/10.

content:
ry 16, 2015
												As in most of the games I play I am very LTTP, but I enjoyed the story lines and world created in this game. While I normally don't play DLC (unless I really enjoyed the main game), I felt like the DLCs in this case built nicely upon what was created in the main game. Dragon Age Awakening was practically a sequel (a short one, but a lot of stand alone games are around the same length).I hate to compare it to Mass Effect, but I am going to anyway. One thing I noticed on my DA play through was I didn't love the characters the same way I loved the ME characters. I didn't make sure I did all the companion quests, etc and didn't even really feel compelled to romance any of the companions. So in a way for me, the story wasn't as character driven as Mass Effect, if that makes sense, but I still found myself enjoying the overall story arc, combat and world.The combat took some getting used to. At first I didn't like the pausing mechanic, but I found later as some of the fights got more complicated in terms of positioning ranged players or having a companion change tactics it made it way more fun. The tactics menu was also an awesome idea. Most of the time I went with the default tactics, but found myself slightly modifying them as I went further into the game. Basically the pausing mechanic and being able to change tactics really added to the game in a big way, setting it apart from other action RPGs.I plan on playing DA2 soon, but I don't own it on Steam unfortunately.

content:
er 17, 2013
												Dragon Age, when it arrived, was a game that I had been waiting on for a very long time. Having been criminally denied more KotOR (which is what I truly wanted), this was as close as I was going to get to that same feeling; Squad-based tactical RPG with a heavy emphasis on character interaction, development and choice... Just describing it makes me want to fire it up again.The setting and tone is similar to Game of Thrones, but before the show even existed; A dark fantasy that delves into intrigue, mystery, deception and tragedy. Not to mention a heavy dose of epic adventure. Of course the game doesn't always take itself so seriously, taking cues from its predecessor by implementing some charming, quirky characters and an overall sense of hope in the darkness. The consistenly excellent writing, VO and art design all come together in a way that helps you get lost in the universe they created.The story, and how it unfolds, is really quite good. As the name suggests, your origin is important, and what you choose to be at the beginning will have a noticeable impact on your path. However, everyone ultimately finds their way into the arms of the Grey Wardens, a jedi-esque order of warriors devoted to stopping a horde of darkspawn from spreading throughout the land. They recruit you, train you, and before you know it, throw you into the fire. What happens in the next 40-60 hours is for you to discover. That number will of course grow considerably if you get all of the DLC. Origins is unique for a modern Western game, in the sense that it is actually fairly challenging. The enemies, especially a few hours into the game, are tough and it only gets harder. Even on normal difficulty you will likely get your ♥♥♥ kicked a few times, soon to realize that a strategic approach is the best way to succeed. The combat is complex but it makes sense, taking the fundementals of KotOR and making it even deeper.Of course now having said all of that, it looks like I'm going to be playing it soon... You should do the same.

												One of the most excellent WRPGs in recent memory. While things slow down around the Deep Roads, it never fails to add new, imaginative characters and encounters that spice up the game. Combat is a strategic dance, with traditional roles (tank, healer, etc.) and new specializations that fit the unique enemies you fight. Best of all is the interaction system. Each and every character in this game is like a living being, and interacting with them feels natural and realistic. The game always finds ways to test you, whether it be your combat process or your strength of character. 9/10.

content:
19, 2014
												Bioware's Dragon Age: Origins, vanilla or with all the released content for it, has been one of my all-time favorite games, of any genre, of any platform, that I've played since I started gaming back in the early 1980s.  If that isn't enough of a statement to help you decide if this game is good or not, or 'worth it' as so many ask, then I don't know what else I could say to make it so.I just love the storyline and characters so much, to the point that I actually got emotionally tied to some of them.  As the storyline develops, based on your decisions throughout your questing, you'll come to love certain characters, and come to actually hate and loath others.I can bet you, that once you've played through the game a certain way, you'll want to play through again, just to see the storyline from a different perspective, and then yet again.Like for myself, I've played through the vanilla game on Xbox360, then with the DLC packs, then got Awakening to play through it yet again.  But I also wanted to experience the game on my PC so I bought it for my PC as well.  And I'm not done yet...  I just saw the Ultimate Edition on Steam for a crazy low price of $7.49 so I said, "Why not!  I want to have it on Steam as well!  It has EVERYTHING that came out for the game, in one edition.  Well duh, I guess that's why it's called Ultimate Edition I guess, right?"It's just that GOOD!Bottom line is, if you like RPGs and/or Action RPGs, then you have to get this.  You won't be taken seriously when you say you know action RPGs if you've never played it, and that's the truth.Huge thanks Bioware, as if Baldur's Gate wasn't enough of a classic, you give us another.Want to see one of the best game trailers ever made?http://store.steampowered.com/video/17450/5452Feel free to share your favorite characters and why below in the comments.  I'd be very interested in reading your story and take on the game.

content:
er 10, 2013
												A fun game with the best dialogue Bioware has ever done. I'm a HUGE Bioware fanboy and in series like KoToR or Mass Effect you choose either all Good or Bad choices because of an alignment tree, which doesn't allow you to make the character that reflects you. In Dragon age all the choices reflect how you are as a person, no alignment tree no incentives to do everyone good or bad it's how you want to play. It makes you really get lost in this wonderful world. With all that said the combat system is very  unique...and that's not such a good thing. Let's just say I struggled through the combat system and was rewarded with a great story. Although hey you might like it, so it's 100% worth picking up if you want an 80+ hour RPG adventure with lots of very fun DLC.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 18, 2014
												An amazingly immersive RPG with a great story and greater characters. As with most Bioware RPGs the main focus of the game is the story and the moral choices you make; what really impressed me were the choices aren't always clear cut good and bad; those choices not only affect the game but also influence how the characters you travel with feel about you. The combat system is strategic and challenging and playing the PC version means you can easily control the flow of battle with the zoomed out view, allowing you to better plan out your attacks and makes for a more satisfying experience than it's console counterpart. The character customisation is extensive and choosing the origin story really feels as though your character is fleshed out but don't expect too much from the origin story later in game as it only affects minor aspects of the dialogue and unique encounter for each origin. Dragon Age is a very good all round RPG which you will easily sink hours into, plus it has an impressive catalogue of mods which can really add to the game so be sure to check those out too!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2014
												Bioware's Dragon Age: Origins, vanilla or with all the released content for it, has been one of my all-time favorite games, of any genre, of any platform, that I've played since I started gaming back in the early 1980s.  If that isn't enough of a statement to help you decide if this game is good or not, or 'worth it' as so many ask, then I don't know what else I could say to make it so.I just love the storyline and characters so much, to the point that I actually got emotionally tied to some of them.  As the storyline develops, based on your decisions throughout your questing, you'll come to love certain characters, and come to actually hate and loath others.I can bet you, that once you've played through the game a certain way, you'll want to play through again, just to see the storyline from a different perspective, and then yet again.Like for myself, I've played through the vanilla game on Xbox360, then with the DLC packs, then got Awakening to play through it yet again.  But I also wanted to experience the game on my PC so I bought it for my PC as well.  And I'm not done yet...  I just saw the Ultimate Edition on Steam for a crazy low price of $7.49 so I said, "Why not!  I want to have it on Steam as well!  It has EVERYTHING that came out for the game, in one edition.  Well duh, I guess that's why it's called Ultimate Edition I guess, right?"It's just that GOOD!Bottom line is, if you like RPGs and/or Action RPGs, then you have to get this.  You won't be taken seriously when you say you know action RPGs if you've never played it, and that's the truth.Huge thanks Bioware, as if Baldur's Gate wasn't enough of a classic, you give us another.Want to see one of the best game trailers ever made?http://store.steampowered.com/video/17450/5452Feel free to share your favorite characters and why below in the comments.  I'd be very interested in reading your story and take on the game.

content:
14, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins sets itself apart from other games of it's genre.  The story is phenomenal to say the least, the characters are some of the deepest, well-thought figures in any game I've ever played, and the RPG element allows the player direct decisions on nearly every aspect of the game.  When 'epic, fantasy RPG' comes to mind, DA:O is truly the elite in it's class.  The Ultimate Edition is no exception, great price for value.I'm a long time console player with probably several hundred hours and atleast 5 playthroughs, but I have yet to complete my first playthrough of the game and all the DLC on the PC yet and already have 80+ hours logged.  You heard correctly; 80+ hours on one character and I've only completed the base game, Warden's Peak, Stone Prisoner, and Golem's of Amgarrak.  I have yet to complete Awakening, Witch Hunt, Leliana's Song, and Darkspawn Invasion.  I expect the total hours to be 120+ on one character by the time I have done everything the Ultimate Edition has to offer.  Easily one of the best values for dollar per hour spent.The combat may be the only draw-back to the game.  Strategy-wise, it's extremely in-depth and requires much preparation on higher difficulties.  Veteran MMO players will feel right at home.  However the visuals are lacking (keeping in mind the date of release) and the whole system isn't very 'exhilarating', though you'll feel the occasional rush during a boss fight.  The combat serves its purpose and doesn't really throw any curves; it doesn't add much noteworthy additions to the game, but it certainly does not detract from the piece.The vanilla game is stellar in itself, but the incorporation of the DA Updater allows easy organization of mods.  Mods I've found especially good include textures, re-skins, graphics, combat AI, and combat tactics.Overall, one of the best modern RPG's in existence.  Give it a shot if you haven't, you won't regret it.10/10

content:
, 2013
												You don't have this? GO BUY IT! I loved playing this game, Bioware managed to do a pretty good job with Dragon Age, even more than Mass Effect in my honest opinion. The story explains very well what is happening in the game world without anything sounding "awkward". The story is one of the best I've experienced lately but it kinda feels they are doing the same they did with Mass Effect, a special organization (Specters/Grey Wardens) fighting to save the day from evil (Reapers/DarkSpawn). But in the end, I enjoyed it very much. The combat handles pretty well and it feels solid, at first I didn't really liked it but after a while I got used to it and now, I adore it. The skill tree and the ammount of options you have that will affect how the game unfolds are surprisingly very good. I wouldn't say the looting system is the best, it's certainly mediocre. With tons of crafting along with runecrafting that there's in the game and the small but good amount of content that Awakening brings into the base game I'd say that this were around 99 hours very well spent and I recommend this RPG to anyone that loves a good story, a good fantasy world and a good experience.

content:
y 29, 2014
												So I know that Steam says I've played only 91.3hrs, but I've played offline as well, and it's a total of about 125+ hours. I ADORE this game. It is absolutely worth it to buy the Ultimate Edition-however, I bought it on sale for $7.40 (midweek madness is GODSEND). The extra content is very useful (there's items, gifts and and even 2 map locations, as well as an additional party member) and the additional campaigns are very fun.The story is very well developed, as are the characters. They're very vivid. The graphics are also fabulous. What I love the most about the story is how OPTIONAL it is; you can skip cutscenes by pressing escape, as well as dialogue. Much of the story comes from talking to NPC's as well as your party members, so if you are not a fan of story and are just there for the gameplay, you can easily skip it and go about your business.The gameplay itself can be tricky for those not familiar with the tactics system. I played Final Fantasy 12 and there they called it "gambit" system, where basically you can set up a list of tasks for each character to go through during a battle, which makes more strategy possible. However, unlike Final Fantasy 12's gambit system, selecting a character will prevent them from going through their tactics; they will only perform those tasks automatically if you're NOT using them. But if you don't want to set up each individual task, or aren't sure what you'll need, you can select from the premade tactics.Also, an important note: leveling up can be difficult because monsters don't respawn. For this reason, I recommend exploring as much as you can and completing a few side quests. There's tons of side quests available in almost every town you visit.The exploration CAN be a little linear, though. For example, you are unable to jump over objects or vault from cliffs (that was fun in Fable 2). Plus, when traveling from town to town, you go to a loading screen, and observe the map as you travel. There are random encounters that can occur, but it's definitely not as free exploration like Skyrim or Oblivion.All in all, this game is a lot of fun, and it just draws you in. I am very glad I purchased it. I tell all of my friends to buy this game because it's so incredible :)

content:
er 24, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins is a great game, and the Ultimate Edition is the way to go as it includes every single piece of DLC released for the game. Everybody raves about this game, but rarely are the shortcomings addressed:- Animations are dull and stiff (during both combat and dialogue)- Character models have only a few different variations, (so you'll see the same haircuts etc. over and over again) - The overall story arc is rather generic, (hey, you're the hero, go collect everyone and prepare for a final battle)- Depending on what classes you play as, combat can be mind numbingly slow and weak (in particular for any ranged spec rogue, or sword/shield spec warrior)- The world is kind of presented in a rather dull manner- Several bugs (lots of crashing in Origins, and many other technical ones in Awakening)Most of these issues can be ignored because of the other great content in the game. There are some intriguing side quests, interesting companion characters, tough decisions, there's loads replayability and the lore is really deep and well written. For me personally, most of the issues are fixed in Dragon Age II (though that game also brings forward some new issues...)Overall, it's still a great game, I'd give it a flat 8.0/10. But again, for all the praise it gets, it's flaws are never talked about.

content:
25, 2016
												This is less a review of Origins by itself, and more a review of the Dragon age Series as a whole.  Heavily opinionated and spoilers ahead, so be warned.If you like D&D style fights with an element of chance, and overcoming pitted battles with a tactical mindset, then Dragon Age: Origins is for you.  There are a few exploits here and there, but this game glitters like a ruby among RPGs released within the last few years.  I Just wish Inquisition was available through steam.  (And that it was more like DA:O.  It's got the hallmark sins of modern RPGs being too damn flashy.  This is supposed to be a Western RPG series, not a JRPG series.)And don't waste your energy on DA2.  It's a mess.  Watch a playthrough instead, you will get to experience a decent story without having to sit through gameplay that's trash comppared to DA:O.All top-down tactical RPGs should emulate Origins, I hope the next Dragon Age game takes cues from the Witcher and backs off from the cartoony flashy power activation nonsense that belongs in WoW and JRPGs. The series needs to get back in touch with its dark fantasy roots. I don't care if people think its gross or offensive.  Don't let trying to be politically correct limit you creatively  Perfectionism is the enemy of creativity, and trying to make a perfect game that pleases everyone will just land you with something dull and fangless.The Darkspawn in Inquisition were like boring zombies...While the Darkspawn in THIS game are like horrible scabby mutants with mouths full of corroded pointy snake teeth.  Their faces permanently twisted into manic grins of madness, gibbering in their gutteral and violent tongue.You're doing something wrong when your race of subterranean ♥♥♥♥-orcs comes off as boring and inoffensive.  They NEED to be disgusting, they NEED to be cruel in order for a player to feel invested in going in and seeking every little pocket of darkspawn lurking in the shadows.  Each kill is a small victory, each Hurlocke beheaded is a dwarven woman that doesn't need to suffer mutation and mutilation at the hands of darkspawn captors, each Ogre slaughtered is a caravan of soldiers that gets to go home to their families alive and not in boxes of bloodied paste.Recapture 30% of that, and Dragon age 4 will be a hit.

content:
25, 2016
												This is less a review of Origins by itself, and more a review of the Dragon age Series as a whole.  Heavily opinionated and spoilers ahead, so be warned.If you like D&D style fights with an element of chance, and overcoming pitted battles with a tactical mindset, then Dragon Age: Origins is for you.  There are a few exploits here and there, but this game glitters like a ruby among RPGs released within the last few years.  I Just wish Inquisition was available through steam.  (And that it was more like DA:O.  It's got the hallmark sins of modern RPGs being too damn flashy.  This is supposed to be a Western RPG series, not a JRPG series.)And don't waste your energy on DA2.  It's a mess.  Watch a playthrough instead, you will get to experience a decent story without having to sit through gameplay that's trash comppared to DA:O.All top-down tactical RPGs should emulate Origins, I hope the next Dragon Age game takes cues from the Witcher and backs off from the cartoony flashy power activation nonsense that belongs in WoW and JRPGs. The series needs to get back in touch with its dark fantasy roots. I don't care if people think its gross or offensive.  Don't let trying to be politically correct limit you creatively  Perfectionism is the enemy of creativity, and trying to make a perfect game that pleases everyone will just land you with something dull and fangless.The Darkspawn in Inquisition were like boring zombies...While the Darkspawn in THIS game are like horrible scabby mutants with mouths full of corroded pointy snake teeth.  Their faces permanently twisted into manic grins of madness, gibbering in their gutteral and violent tongue.You're doing something wrong when your race of subterranean ♥♥♥♥-orcs comes off as boring and inoffensive.  They NEED to be disgusting, they NEED to be cruel in order for a player to feel invested in going in and seeking every little pocket of darkspawn lurking in the shadows.  Each kill is a small victory, each Hurlocke beheaded is a dwarven woman that doesn't need to suffer mutation and mutilation at the hands of darkspawn captors, each Ogre slaughtered is a caravan of soldiers that gets to go home to their families alive and not in boxes of bloodied paste.Recapture 30% of that, and Dragon age 4 will be a hit.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins is a great game, and the Ultimate Edition is the way to go as it includes every single piece of DLC released for the game. Everybody raves about this game, but rarely are the shortcomings addressed:- Animations are dull and stiff (during both combat and dialogue)- Character models have only a few different variations, (so you'll see the same haircuts etc. over and over again) - The overall story arc is rather generic, (hey, you're the hero, go collect everyone and prepare for a final battle)- Depending on what classes you play as, combat can be mind numbingly slow and weak (in particular for any ranged spec rogue, or sword/shield spec warrior)- The world is kind of presented in a rather dull manner- Several bugs (lots of crashing in Origins, and many other technical ones in Awakening)Most of these issues can be ignored because of the other great content in the game. There are some intriguing side quests, interesting companion characters, tough decisions, there's loads replayability and the lore is really deep and well written. For me personally, most of the issues are fixed in Dragon Age II (though that game also brings forward some new issues...)Overall, it's still a great game, I'd give it a flat 8.0/10. But again, for all the praise it gets, it's flaws are never talked about.

content:
6, 2015
Very quick review:Well worth the money for a memorable RPG that can be played in so many ways. Fulfilling, funny, and completely engaging from start to finish. Minor flaws are forgivable and ignorable for the most part. Absolutely brilliant.Slightly less quick review:Pros:+ Overall gameplay is fantastic – flaws are not overly bothersome.+ Main storyline is excellent – very satisfying and great value for money in terms of length, involvement, and balance of fetch-type quests vs more intricate jobs.+ Side quests are interesting and don’t feel like chores.+ Character development is perfect – you’ll want to do those side quests!+ Customisation: great choice of unique starting points and character builds makes for unrivalled replay value.+ Incredible writing. Draws you in from the very start with whichever character build and story you’ve chosen and is genuinely hilarious at times.+ Voice acting is fantastic.+ Well-developed and immersive world build and lore, but not boring.+ Decisions actually matter.+ Great soundtrack.+ Good mod support.Cons: - Graphics are a bit outdated – high settings or a couple of mods can help, but it’s not horrendous.- Combat mechanics aren’t perfect – a bit slow at times and it takes some getting used to.- You might cry a bit.- You might also laugh till you pee a little. Down to business:Just as a starter, I adore this game. It’s one of my all-time favourites. The DA franchise is amazing, and although Origins is no spring chicken, it has aged well. On higher settings the game still has spectacular moments, graphically speaking, and the mid-low range settings are playable and artistically enjoyable, although not the best by any means. But you won’t care. At all.If you’re looking for an entertaining, fulfilling, thoroughly immersive RPG with brilliant writing and touching character development, grab this. As someone who has also read the Dragon Age novels because she was desperate for more, I can tell you the world build is incredible – the lore is well structured, believable, and gripping. But for those of you who don’t want to read codex or journal entries, with this, you really don’t need to – you’ll be drawn in by the game itself, which expertly takes you through a robust storyline and gives you just the right amount of info to keep you interested without being boring or overwhelming.Your companions will give you feels. Some you’ll hate, some will make you laugh, and some you’ll go full Hulk mode to protect.As far as mechanics go, it’s not perfect – combat is a little slow and clunky at times, and it can take a little while to get used to. The multitude of tactical options and talent customisations available may be a little overwhelming to start with, especially if you’re not used to RPG builds. However, this is more than compensated for. Put simply, you can play whichever way you want. If you enjoy micromanaging and tactical play, the game deals very well with this. If you’d rather be more hands-on, or a mixture of both, go ahead – the AI is pretty good at letting your party get on with it while you smash some darkspawn skulls in with a sword as long as your own body, or go full mage-rage and burn someone to a crisp. As for your actual character – the game does the (mostly) silent protagonist thing very well. It takes nothing away from the enjoyment of this game. The voice acting as a whole is excellent – very believable, very natural, and the right amount of comic relief vs. dramatic, feel-inducing bits. It’s all very epic but not over-acted.The story customisation is second to none. At the start of the game, you can build your male or female character from scratch (or just use the presets) – human, elf, or dwarf; warrior, rogue or mage; noble or bottom of the pile - these options DO make a huge difference to the story. Replay value is amazing. You basically have multiple different games, and the choices you make as you progress shape the world around you as you deal with the Blight. As far as DLC goes, Awakening is brilliant. You can take your story and character forward from the ending of Origins itself, or you can create another new one! It’s another good chunk of gameplay, with fantastic characters and plenty more to do. The other extras are great value too – not to spoil anything, they’re perfect for those wanting a little more from certain characters, and are well worth the play time. Moving forward to DA:2, you can take your Origins story along with you – yay for transferrable save files! Or you can custom-build a story if you weren’t exactly happy with your Origins playthrough and can’t be arsed to do another one. What more could you want?Overall, DA:O is one of the best RPGs I’ve played to date. The characters, the world, and the general gameplay are too much fun to be dented by the flaws in mechanics. It’s something I will happily replay over and over again.
