content:
31, 2013
												Grab your sword and shield because we're going on an adventure, First stop, Being born. Then we're off to fight rats in the kitchen, find your trusty mutt who turns out to be smarter than everyone else in the kingdom, seduce a visiting princess and head to bed where you're awoken by a siege to your castle. The rest of the game is a trudge across a wonderfully bland landscape dotted here and there by complete nonsense quests like Explore the dangerous swamp until you meet a sexy teenage witch who doesn't turn you into a frog. Kill ten gnolls along the way.Racist stereotypes abound, as the only intentionally attractive male character has blonde hair and blue eyes and casts snarky comments the entire adventure, and you're introduced to the party's only black character by finding him naked, shackled in a cage and saying he belongs there. You have the option to free him and bring him as a servant if you go through a complicated back'n'forth with the village leader, who hates dark skin. But in all seriousness this game is pretty chill, it's a 100+ hour modern day Baldur's Gate with decent characters, so if you're looking for another Baldur's Gate fix and don't have ADD you should consider this.Mods that are must haves:Advanced TacticsCharacter Respec ModDetailed TooltipsMadd Gift Guide + AwakeningMorrigan 3.3 and Leliana 2.8 (their default faces are fugly)No Helmet Hack + Awakening (not a single good looking helm in this game)Pretty Faces (NPC faces are fugly)Skip the Fade Manual (don't even question this, this lets you skip the ♥♥♥♥♥iest part of the game)Storage Chest (an official mod by a dev, that wasn't but into the game...)Unlock 25 Tactic Slots Extendedv2 No more Snarling (shuts that damn dog up at the camp)

content:
2013
												Hi, do you like the Baldur's Gate series? What about Planescape: Torment? Icewind Dale? Mass effect with swords and deeper character interaction? Dragon Age: Origins was made by BioWare, the makers of Baldur's Gate, to be the spiritual successor to that very same Baldur's Gate. Imagine that! Spoiler Alert: They succeeded with that.  While not without it's minor flaws, Dragon Age: Origins has the deepest dialogue and interaction with NPC party members since... well, Baldur's Gate. It's not *as* deep as Baldur's Gate or Torment, but it is certainly deeper than Mass Effect. Anyone who enjoyed any of those games should play this. Oh, and don't play Dragon Age 2. It's crap, and was really dumbed down to be a straight console game rather than a PC RPG ported to console. It's really dull, so unless that's your thing just pass on the sequel.

content:
er 9, 2014
												Crashes and Freezes abound in this game. I remember having problems when originally trying to play the game in 2009 and for some reason it's worse with modern day (2014) hardware.That aside, DA is a classic. A quick history: BioWare originally gained fame by creating isometric tactical RPGs in the Dungeons and Dragons (Forgotten Realms) setting. I never looked this up, but my guess is that some suit at Hasbro wasn't able to continue that relationship with BioWare (and ultimately Electronic Arts) and so they created their own setting to create a franchise around at or around which became the Dragon Age universe.In contrast to the High Fantasy themes of Forgotten Realms, the campaign setting of Dragon Age is more Low Fantasy or Dark Fantasy. Magic is to be feared, the mood is dark and gritty, you are surrounded by despair and (to some degree) magic items are a little rare. Also in contrast to any D&D setting, characters do not seem to have direct relationships with gods (or Gods) and do not attain magical powers (i.e. healing) from them. In other words, there are healing schools in magic and no clerics.Differences in the campaign aside, DA is EXACTLY what you would expect from a BioWare game. You have exactly the same viewpoint and controls as seen in Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and Neverwinter. Interactions with NPCs and companions is exactly as you would see in Mass Effect (which is the natural extension of the previously mentioned games).Lots of replay value is inherent with the different starting areas, different ways in which to approach quests and companions and multiple side quests. However, not NEARLY as much open endness within the world if you are to compare to a Bethesda, Elder Scrolls game. Multiple mods exist to enhance the game as well (check Nexus Mods)DA is a classic RPG. Whether you like it or not, however, depends on your style of RPG. Obviously it's a single player game. It's not a JRPG. It's not as open as Elder Scrolls. Tactics are of moderate importance within encounters. Lots of scripted (voice acted) dialogue with NPCs with 'some' variation, but in the end moderately rail-roaded.

content:
r 1, 2015
												Dragon Age Origins: Ultimate EditionPositives:+ This game is a tactical based RPG, requiring frequent pauses in combat to issue party orders. Each class has unique strengths and weaknesses, mages, rogues and warriors alike all contribute something special to the battles. The game itself is very challenging but satisfying and fun at the same time.+ Rogues can learn the art of dual wielding and typically fit in as party DPSER, while Mages have access to a plethora of spells, from aoe and single target disables, to healing, revivals, nuke damage and more. Warriors can inflict savage damage with two handed weapons or tank enemies with a shield and armour.+ The dialogue and story in Dragons Age Origins: Ultimate Edition is amazing. Bioware are well known for their fantastic storytelling and this game is no exception. There are memorable characters who you can build friendships with and complete quests for. Romance is also an option. The main plot is well thought-out and maintains your interest. +There's a large number of side quests to complete, around 120 hours of content in total with the expansions. Plenty of moral decision making which impacts on the story progression too.+ Lots of random event encounters, with forests, temples and ancient ruins to explore, along with several cities.Mixed:~ For 2009 the graphics are not the best, but by no means are they terrible. This is definitely no reason to avoid the game.Negatives:- Some redundant skills, like trap making or survival, that don't seem to serve any useful purpose.Overall Score 9/10Dragons Age Origins: Ultimate Edition is a really solid game in pretty much every respect. Well worth purchasing on sale for $10 or less. In fact, many digital distributors are offering this price daily, so don't miss out.

												A Masterpiece game, that is made by a great company in Bioware. Story is always interesting, allowing you to pick your own character race and each one has their own back story. Like playing as a Human Noble, City Elf, Circle Mage, etc. Gameplay is great, with great use of a tactical system and dialogue in-game provides great fun. Graphics are great, with blood and gore. Presentation is like a story book style, and everything is easy to use. Sound in the game is great with amazing atmospheric music, and voice overs are well done. Although, it can be a bit on the low volume, so you might have to crank your volume up more than usual to hear. Also, some DLCs have come out for it to enhance the story even more. Overall, a masterpiece game. I don't remember another RPG like it, maybe except Neverwinter Nights 1

content:
, 2014
												This game was like a great book you just can't put down until you finish. And when it did finish I was left satisfied yet wanting more. A truly immersive experience, I found myself talking to my companions, and laughing at their bickering. It features a great storyline with a different outcome depending on your choices. There is a bit of a morale system in that certain companions will like or dislike your actions and you will gain or lose reputation with them. Some companions have different morals than others so you can choose to take those who will agree with your choices and thus gain rep with them. However for the most part you'll want to choose your companions based on what classes/spells you need for battles. This game can be brutally hard with battles, but it does have a difficulty option which can be changed at any time.If you're a fan of RPG's this is a must-play. It features immersive towns and people, all of which have something to do or say. The world is full and rich, with no "empty" spots. However, the story is somewhat linear, so if you skip something you may not be able to go back later if you go forward in the main quest. Side quests are aplenty as are companions. You may struggle with bag space as you never know what you might need. I got around this by avoiding the crafting specialisations and selling the materials. This left room for all the loot.All in all, I'd give this a 9.5/10. Very few RPG's come close to this immersive experience.

content:

												The characters of Dragon Age are memorable and the story is brutal and interesting. Gameplay of turn based combat is a lot of fun and strategic once you start understanding it. All of the main characters have fair amount of depth to them and they truly feel part of your team.The loot system and gears are varied and pretty cool. You can customize all of your characters in any way you can but a lot of the armors look way too similar and it gets boring to see legendary level armors and weapons that look the same as much cheaper ones.The setting of Dragon Age is both a strength and weakness. The places you go to are memorable and are visually amazing, but there just aren't that many places and they aren't big enough. You basically fast travel from one place to another, and the world doesn't feel big at all.Overall the fantastic story, well done characters and fun combat system definitely makes for a really fun game. The climax of the game also feels epic and hectic. Rating 85

content:

content:
25, 2015
												Do you enjoy rich, engaging stories with branching paths depending on your character's race and class?Do you enjoy tactical combat with lots of room for strategic planning?Do you enjoy game worlds with deep, rich history and lore that spans ages?Do you enjoy having a large group of companions with unique personalities and fighting styles?Do you enjoy games that have different endings depending on your choices?If you answered yes to any of these things, get Dragon Age: Origins right away. Even after several playthroughs over the years, (used to have PS3 version and non-steam pc version) I have yet to see everything in this game. Your save from your DA:O playthrough can be carried over to Dragon Age 2 and your world state after finishing DA 2 can be uploaded to Dragon Age Inquisition via the Dragon Age Keep. Find out for yourself why both fans and critics say that Dragon Age: Origins is one of the best RPG's ever made. This is one of Bioware's best games. A company already known for quality RPGs.

												I cannot say enough good things about Dragon Age: Origins. The storyline, soundtrack, characters.... all of it. It is a masterpiece. Complemented with one of the best game soundtracks of all time, it is a truly immersive experience.This game, in every way, shape, and form is superior to its sequel: Dragon Age 2. content:
y 31
												As a warning, I'm not done with this game yet.This is a story-rich Roleplaying Game where you play as one of the last of an order of protectors fighting to save the world. The setting is a fantasy one with not too many departures from tropes. Characters are generally written well enough. You have a party with which you can develop a variety of relationships including romances. Combat plays like an MMO, but has some extra things that allow you to play more strategically.There's plenty of content and quests to do as well as things to explore in your character's journey.If you like Western RPGs this is well-made one with a story that has depth and a world filled with enemies to rid it of in your travels.

content:
14, 2014
												Customizable characters, difficult decisions (no red or blue or right or wrong like other games), funny dialouge between characters, epic boss fights, weapons, romance, and over 100hrs of gameplay.....What more could you ask for from an RPG game. The main story is amazing. You will laugh, cry, and ponder about you're past decisions as you progress through the many hours of the game. Always was a fan of the original dragon age orgins edition, so buying the Ultimate was a no brainer for me. The DLCs whether following the main story or occuring after the main story may not be the longest, but they are definitely interesting and will leave you wanting to knwo what happens next. The Awakening DLC is fantastic though; being able to lead the Graywardens and make decisions not just for yourself but for a city of people is stressful , but rewarding. Also being able to be reunited with former friends and make many new ones is also a nice change in pace. The darkspawn in this dlc are also more interesting since there are those who talk and do things with a purpose not just because they can. Overall, get this game!!! Whether its the regular edition or the Ultimate Edition, either one wil be worth every last buck.

content:
ber 17, 2014
												I only have like 20 hours on steam with this game, but on console I have well over 200, and I have beaten origins along with awakening with 6 different characters and my favorite to play with is the mage. Having said all of that, this is easily in my top 5 games of all time. I love the story line and how in depth it can get with desicions, and the desicions actually matter in dragon age, they affect quests, what people (mainly your party) think of you, and change the ending. The combat can be a little slow and clunky at times, but this doesnt really deter me. I prefer the big hot bar of spells and talents to the button mash system that is implemented in many newer RPGs (dragon age 2). If you want hours upon hours of in depth gameplay, in depth and deep if not sometimes tear jerking story, character romance, great boss fights with killer rewards then this is the game for you. I highly reccomend it, and at the price it's at now, it's more than worth it.

content:
2, 2012
												the plot of Dragon Age is extremely rich with details that unfold over dozens of hours of play. All of this is documented in your in-game codex, which tracks conversations, plot points and other elements of your journey. The general backstory revolves around the Darkspawn threat to the land of Ferelden. Darkspawn are a race of creatures born from magic users who attempted to become gods, but were cursed for their efforts. Led by the powerful Arch-demon, the beasts emerge from underground lairs every few hundred years in a swarming plague known as the Blight.
